newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Warcrimes tribunal says president not ready to quit.
newsitem.headline: Warcrimes tribunal says president not ready to quit.

text.p: The U.N. criminal tribunal for former Yugoslavia said on Tuesday remarks attributed to its president, Antonio Cassese, that he intented to quit had been misconstrued.
"He (Cassese) has no intention of quitting. He was merely expressing growing impatience with the lack of arrests," Hague-based tribunal spokesman Christian Chartier told Reuters.
The U.S. Christian Science Monitor daily reported on Monday that Cassese had threatened to quit in a speech to a University of Connecticut Law School panel on Saturday.
"If the major powers of the world are not consistent and don't make arrests in the next 10 months, we are prepared to pack up and go home," the newspaper reported him as saying.
Chartier, who said he had spoken to Cassese on Tuesday, said his comments merely meant that unless there were fresh arrests, no more cases would come before the tribunal.
"It was stated as a matter of fact. He has definitely not threatened to resign," Chartier said.
Of the 74 people indicted for war crimes in the former Yugoslavia, only seven are in tribunal custody.
The remainder, including former Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic and his army commander Gen. Ratko Mladic, both charged with genocide, remain at large.
